[MY PREVIOUS ACTION - Turn 22]
Reasoning: **Analyzing My Options in the Shop**

Alright, I'm in the Shop phase of Balatro, Ante 2, Round 2. Let's see... I've got a measly $2. Hmm, not ideal. I'm rocking Four Fingers, To the Moon, and Bootstraps as Jokers – a decent foundation, but I need to survive the next round to continue building.

The shop itself is offering a Celestial Pack for $4 and the Tarot Merchant voucher for a whopping $10. Forget that. I have no consumable cards to use or sell. Rerolling is out of the question as well at $5. Looks like I've already exhausted any immediate card purchases. And selling a Joker? Absolutely not. Four Fingers is critical for reliable hand size, To the Moon keeps the money flowing in this economy build, and Bootstraps is the core of my scaling multiplier. I just bought these, so getting rid of any would be a setback.

So, I'm stuck, which means my only move is to advance to the next round. It's a bit of a gamble, but I see no other viable path.
I'll give the jokers a quick inspection for positioning that matters. Okay, everything's in good shape. Bootstraps is a straight +Mult, so no specific placement is needed at the moment.

Alright, moving on. `round_select` it is.

[MY PREVIOUS ACTION - Turn 23]
Reasoning: **My Strategy: Grind for Capital**

Okay, so we're in Round 2, with the Ante at 2/8. I've got $2, and the game step is BLIND_SELECT. My Jokers are Four Fingers, To the Moon, and Bootstraps. The immediate goal is the Small Blind (800 chips). The Big Blind is 1200 chips after that. And the Boss Blind lurks at 1600 chips, which I don't need to consider right now.

My core strategy hinges on getting "Bootstraps" and "To the Moon" online. Right now, both are doing nothing. "Bootstraps" needs $5 increments for its multiplier, and "To the Moon" needs $5 increments for interest. I only have $2, so these Jokers are sleeping giants.

The decision is: skip the round for a Voucher Tag (adds a voucher to the next shop) or play the Small Blind? Skipping isn't an option. Vouchers are likely to cost $10, and even a great Voucher is useless if I can't afford it. Skipping also means missing out on the $3 round reward.

Playing the round is the *only* way to get started. I need cash. I expect to get at least $3 for winning the round, plus maybe $1 for a hand bonus. That puts me at around $6. That will net me $2 interest with "To the Moon." With $8, I’m getting somewhere. More importantly, playing the round gives me a chance to build up my money so I can use my Jokers.

"Four Fingers" is a real blessing here. It makes it easier to hit flushes and straights, which means I can reach the Small Blind even without any multiplier from "Bootstraps". I need to be aiming for those hands to generate money.

So, the action is `play_round`. The reasoning is simple: I need to generate capital. Skipping is a dead end. Playing the round is the only way forward.



Command: play_round

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
